title: 2010-07-30 - CVE-2010-2568 keylogger Win32-Chymine.A
plain_text:
# CVE-2010-2568 keylogger Win32/Chymine.A

**[contagiodump.blogspot.com/2010/07/cve-2010-2568-keylogger-win32chyminea.html](http://contagiodump.blogspot.com/2010/07/cve-2010-2568-keylogger-win32chyminea.html)**

CVE-2010-2568 - Win32/Chymine.A
Windows Shell in Microsoft Windows XP SP3, Server 2003 SP2, Vista SP1 and SP2, Server
2008 SP2 and R2, and Windows 7 allows local users or remote attackers to execute arbitrary
[code via a crafted (1) .LNK or (2) .PIF shortcut file, which is not properly handled during icon](http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2010-2568)
display in Windows Explorer, as demonstrated in the wild in July 2010, and originally
reported for malware that leverages CVE-2010-2772 in Siemens WinCC SCADA systems

The credit for this post goes to Extraexploit from extraexploit.blogspot.com. See additional
details on his blog

Download bin.exe as a password protected archive (contact me if you need the

password)

[ESET New malicious LNKs: here we goâ€¦](http://blog.eset.com/2010/07/22/new-malicious-lnks-here-we-go)

"At the time of analysis, this threat downloads and install a key stroke logger which we
detect as Win32/Spy.Agent.NSO trojan. The server used to deliver the components
used in this attack is presently located in the US, but the IP is assigned to a customer
in China. "


-----
